Entry.1:
'16

Left Hurdcott at 9p.m. last night & marched to Wilton where we entrained for Folkstone arriving at 6a.m. where we breakfasted. Crossed the channel to Boulogne at 11a.m. & went into rest camp for the rest of the day.
Entry.2: We left Boulogne by train at 11a.m. & travelled 15 miles to Etaples (pronounced Etaps) where we are now in the "base depot".
Entry.3:
Did nothing all day. We are beside the Black Watch here, they are great fellows. These cats are practically the only ones of the British forces that

 have much to do with the Austs. They are very fine fellows & they would sooner have the Australians to fight beside than any others.
Entry.4: Church this morning & nothing else much all day.
Entry.5: Spell today. I went to Communion this morning & then had a spell the rest of the day. We are not allowed down in the town of Etaples.
Entry.6:
Dec.i^

Had a kit inspection this morning & a route march in the afternoon. The town is a fearfully dirty place & I am not sorry we are not allowed down town as it is a fearful place.
Entry.7: Route march this morning. Of course we are only about two miles off the sea & only 80 miles from the firing line. We went to the "bull ring" that is the training camp where all the bayonet fighting & that sort of thing. We were also issued with our gas helmets.
Entry.8: Bull Ring again where we went through the gas chamber with our gas helmets on just to get us used it Then had several lectures & a little bombing.
Entry.9: It has been raining pretty well ever since we came here. This morning we had several lectures & tonight we went out for night operations. When we got out about three miles it came on to rain very heavily & we turned round & came back.
Entry.10: Marched four miles out to Kangaroo Range where we fired fifteen rounds apiece.
Entry.11: Church parade & saw off a draft including Sgt. McKenzie.
Entry.12: Route march in the morning & a rifle cleaning parade in the afternoon.
Entry.13: Two route marches one in the morning & one in the afternoon behind a rotten band. We were paid tonight in French money.
Entry.14: Two route marches again today. I had to take off one of the stripes today. We will all have to take them off when we go to the line but they had too many sgts. so several of us had to drop one today. We are not allowed to go into Etaples but it is the dirtiest place ever you saw.
Entry.15:
Jan..	Corey

Yesterday while out on a route march I came against Ernie Cory in the 55th. He tells me that Lorrie Crisp & two of the Smiths are in the same Battalion & are only two lines away from us in this camp. Two route marches today & had just got into bed when at 8 o'clock the orderly sgt. came in & told two of us to go down to the Hospital siding to act as guides to a draft coming in from Overseas. Got to the siding at 8.30 & waited till 12.30. Two troop trains came in but were both full of Tommies & Scotties & no Australians. A big hospital train came in while we were waiting. The hospital trains are beautifully fitted up. I almost wished I was one of the patients myself.
Entry.16: Had a spell off this morning in consideration of last nights work. Route march in the afternoon.
Entry.17: Two route marches today and tonight went to hear a very good lecture on the war by Mr Lowell.
Entry.18: Church parade in the morning and spell in the afternoon.
Entry.19: Route march in the morning and rain in the afternoon.
Entry.20: Rain sleet and snow all day with route march in afternoon
Entry.21:
Snowed and rained all day so we had the day off but I was unfortunate enough to 

to have to take out a fatigue in the afternoon about three miles & back so we got rather wet 11. Jan,

No parade in the morning & a short route march in the afternoon.
Entry.22: Route march in the morning & went to rifle range in the afternoon where we fired fifteen rounds each
Entry.23:
Jan,

Went out to the bull ring where we did a little training out there.
Entry.24: Church parade in the morning & spell in the afternoon. This evening I found Reg Edols he was warned for draft tonight & I believe he is going in the morning.
Entry.25: Bull Ring parade today & trained there all day.
Entry.26: Two short route marches today & nothing else.
Entry.27: Snow has been falling all day. We had clothes washing parade this morning & no parade this afternoon.
Entry.28: Bull Ring parade today & tonight I got a parcel from home posted on the 10th Oct
Entry.29:
Jan,

Bull Ring parade again today.
Entry.31:
Jan,

Church Parade this morning & spell this afternoon.
Entry.35: Bull Ring parade & when we came home found Vigaro sitting in the tent
Entry.37: Bull Ring parade and warned for draft tonight.
Entry.39: Two short route marches and standing by all day.
Entry.40: Issued with tin hats and a route march.
Entry.41: Route march in the morning and standing by all the afternoon.
Entry.42: Kit inspection in morning and short route march in the afternoon.
Entry.44: Route march and in the afternoon escorted men to hospital
Entry.45: Church parade and the rest of the day off. Still waiting to go up the line but we havenot gone yet.
Entry.46: Reveille at 2.30 and entrained at 8 am arrived at Albert at 5 pm and billeted there for night.
Entry.47: Left Albert at 3 pm and marched about six miles to camp arriving at 7.30 pm.
Entry.48: Had a spell all morning and are to leave here at 3 pm. For the line. Reached the front line about 7.30 pm and put in the night there.
Entry.49:
All day in the trenches and came out about five miles to huts 

10th.Feb.

Came back about three miles to hut, for a few days rest . We are still within reach of Fritz`s guns. Montaban is the place.
Entry.50: Church parade this morning and spell the rest of the day.
Entry.51: Had a spell all day and expect the move again tomorrow.
Entry.52: Left Montauban at 2 oclock and came back to C Camp at Bernafaye Wood. About 5 oclock twelve of us were detailed to carry tea up about three miles to a work party. Got back at 9.30 pm
Entry.53: Nothing doing today but a few fatigues.
Entry.54: Spell this morning and are to go up into supports tonight at about five oclock.
Entry.55:
In supports all day and did nothing until tonight when we did a fatigue. Things are fairly quiet today. We have not been shelled all day.

17thFeb.

Spell all day and fatigue all night up to the knee in mud and slush and got back here at 4.30 am after sapping all night in front of our front line.
Entry.56: Are to go up to the front line for three days I believe, just got two small parcels of socks one from Glenelg and one from Rhyana.
Entry.57: Came into the line last night after doing two trips of fatigues.
Entry.58: Spent last night in a shell hole in an advance position.
Entry.59: Again spent the night in a shell hole up to the knees in water and are to go out tonight.
Entry.60: Came out to C Camp last night and back to Montauban to day. The mud was something terrible in the line this time.
Entry.61: Spell all day today and were given a clean change of clothes.
Entry.62: Rifle inspection and spell. Spent the day looking for a canteen to get a feed.
Entry.63: Spell all day and heard all sorts of war ruoumours.
Entry.64: Spell all day and roumours increase.
Entry.66: Still doing nothing and wondering what is going to happen.
Entry.68: Did a guard last night & had a bath & change of clothes in the morning. Moved back to C Camp Bernafay Wood in the afternoon.
Entry.69: Did a fatigue carrying barbed wire.
Entry.70: Fatigue in the morning & came up to Switch trench in the afternoon* Snowed all the morning.
Entry.71: Stayed in the Switch trench all day & moved up to Rose trench tonight.
Entry.73: Stayed here both days & to go up to the front line tonight.
Entry.74: I acted as stretcher bearer & sat in a dug out all day. Fritz made it very warm all day but we had only one walking case.
Entry.75: It was pretty hot again today & we had one stretcher case tonight- It took us three hours to get him out. Were relieved at about 12.30 & took four hours to get back to C Camp.
Entry.76: Got to bed about 4.30 this morning & had a spell all day.
Entry.78: Had a bath & went out to Needle trench for Soup Container.
Entry.79: Fatigue in the morning at Waterlot Farm & came to Millers Son for ration fatigue at night
Entry.80: Spell all day carried rations at night & had to stand by all night.
Entry.81: Spell all day & carried rations again at night
Entry.82:
St Patricks Day.

Called out at 8 o'clock to go to the front line in daylight. When we got there Fritz had evacuated so we advanced, occupied his front line & then advanced to Buelencourt & took a position about live hundred yards beyond the village which we held until night fall when we were relieved by the 56th & returned to Millers Son. I was stretcher bearing. We dressed a couple of men from other companies but had no casualties ourselves.
Entry.83:
19th & 2oth Mar.

Remained in the dug out at Millers Son & had a spell
Entry.84: Went out to Bemafay for a bath, got our wash & returned to the dugout
Entry.85: Fatigue in the morning & got our packs off the trucks.
Entry.86: Moved to Rumcourt where we are camped in ruined houses.
Entry.88: Did road fatigues all day repairing the roads.
Entry.89: Road fatigues again. In the rain.
Entry.91: Moved forward about 5 kilometres to a village where we stored our packs & went on to the front line,
Entry.92: Got a slight wound with a piece of shrapnel & had to go & get it dressed. Was sent on to Bapaume to dressing station
Entry.93: Went on to Main dressing station at Poizeres & at night came on to No. 9 Casualty Cleaning Station at Aveluy near Albert
Entry.95: Went onto the Hospital Train at Aveling at 3 pm and arrived at Rouen at 2 am. The following morning where I was admitted to No.12 General Hospital.
Entry.96: Transferred to No. 2 Convalescence Camp about a mile from the hospital
Entry.97: Sent to rest camp 46th I.B.D. behind No. 12 General.
Entry.98: Went out to Rouen Bull Ring.
Entry.99: Left Rouen at 2p.m. for the base.
Entry.101: Left Etaples at 8 rn.m. & arrived at Albert at 3p.m. where we detrained.
Entry.102: Left Albert at 11a.m. & marched to Perth Camp near Bernafay.
Entry.103: Did a salvaging fatigue picking up empty shell cases.
Entry.104: Fatigue carrying duckboards on the railway.
Entry.106: Moved off at 12.30p.m. & marched to Becourt about 2 miles from Albert where we joined the battalion.
Entry.107:
Church parade in the morning.

23rd*

Squad drill in the morning & joined the Lewis Gunners at 2.30p.m.
Entry.108: Fatigue getting the ground ready for the sports.
Entry.110: Drill today & mounted anti-aircraft guard tonight
Entry.111: Guard all day but managed to see football match
Entry.113: Lewis Gun Drill & firing the Gun.
Entry.114: Gun drill and went on fire piquet at night.
Entry.115: Firing on the rifle range today.
Entry.118:
Divisional sports in the afternoon.

5th

Drill in the morning and horse show in the afternoon.
Entry.120: Suddenly received orders to move. Went from Albert to Bapaume by train and marched out about three miles.
Entry.121: Did nothing all day and moved up to reserves at night about six miles
Entry.122: About 3 miles from front line. The rest of Coy did fatigue in line at night but Lewis gunners did not go. Shelled us a bit about 8.30 pm.
Entry.123: Were shelled occasionally all day again gunners did not go on fatigue.
Entry.124: Heavy bombardment tonight from our side and a few from Fritz. Helped to carry a man out about 11pm.
Entry.125: Fritz shelled us pretty heavily in the afternoon and nearly dug us out of our home.
Entry.126: Moved up to sunken road to supports.
Entry.127: Bombarded heavily all day and ration fatigue at night when he sent over some gas shells and we could not go up till morning.
Entry.128: Fritz came over in the morning but was repulsed we had to go up to reinforce in the afternoon.
Entry.130: Remained in the front line and came back to Neuriel on night of
Entry.131: fairly quiet while we were in.
Entry.132: Spell all day and fatigue at night.
Entry.133: Water fatigue at front line at night.
Entry.134: Went for a walk over to Lagnicourt where we got some rhubarb and gooseberries and pansies. Water fatigue at night.
Entry.135: Went to front line at night on right of where we were last time. I was no 2 on the gun.
Entry.138: Quiet again and relieved by the R.Bs at about 11.30 pm.
Entry.139: Came out to Vaulx which we reached at daylight. Left Vaulx at 11am and marched to Beaulin court where we are in tents.
Entry.140: Did odd jobs all day and moved all the tents.
Entry.148: Entrained at Bapaume and came down to Warloy to billets
Entry.149: I had leave into Amiens today. It is about 16 miles from here and we went in by train.
Entry.150: Inspected by General Birdwood and Mar Holman Bindy presented a number of medals.
Entry.151: Leave to Amiens and pay at night
Entry.155: Went to lewis gun school at Aveluy
Entry.157: Walked out to Maily to battalion to see if there were any letters
Entry.159: Marched to detail camp at Becourt
Entry.160: Went to Herassart on motor lorries to join the battalion
Entry.161: Batgtn parade in morning and were inspected by Birdwood in the afternoon when he presented a number of medals.
Entry.162: Route march out for a swim.
Entry.163: We have orders to move off at 12 pm tonight to entrain to go somewhere up north
Entry.164: We entrained at 2am and came to Arques arriving at 11 am.We marched aboaut 8 kilometres to billets. We are about 30 kilos from Ypres here.
Entry.165: Marched about 2 kilos to Eblingham where we got on motors and came to Nielles about 20 miles from Boulougne
Entry.167: sDid stunts each day about four miles from where we were billeted.
Entry.168: Marched to Timbres 5 miles came to Arques by motor lorry and marched back to the old biallets at Emblingham.
Entry.171: Expect to move tomorrow, church parade today
Entry.173: Marched 8 miles to tents about three miles from Poperingh, crossing Belgian border about 11 am.
Entry.174: Marched about 8 miles at night to behind Ypres.
Entry.176: Expect to move tonight to support,.
Entry.178: Early in morning moved back about half a mile. We were reserve battn for a hop over by several divisions attack was successful but we suffered a few casualties in supports.
Entry.179: Came back as far as the “halfway house"
Entry.181: Came back about five miles tonight and camped under canvas
Entry.182: Came back to the old camp near Poperingh
Entry.183: Twelve months today since we sailed
Entry.184: Moved forward about four miles to huts
Entry.187: Did fatigues digging a trench for cables
Entry.190:
21st

Did ration fatigues and moved back to Zillabeke camp , the last night.
Entry.192: Moved back to billets near Abeele
Entry.193: Marched about twelve miles to Outerstein
Entry.194: Moved up about 9 miles to Loire to hut
Entry.195: Moved up about six kilos to tents near Hemmel
Entry.196: Moved about a kilometre to dugouts at Irish House
Entry.197: Was detailed to take charge of a guard over several men awaiting court martial
Entry.198: Moved the Guard back to billets in Hemmel where the battalion joined us coming out of the line.
Entry.200: Marched two miles and entrained to Deverises where we billeted for the night.
Entry.201: Marched 17 miles to Frang about 8 kilos from Etaples
Entry.202: Ourf new colonel arrived and we had a battalion parade for his inspection. It is twelve months today since we left Hurdcott
Entry.203: One year today since I landed in France.
Entry.204:
.

Walked into Etaples about 9 kilometres – arriving home at about 10 pm we did not see the old year out.
Entry.205: Walked to Etaples and went by train from there to Boulougne on my way to a school.
Entry.206: Caught train at 12.50 am and reached Abeele at 9.15 am We had about four kilometres to march to the school at Boescliff.
Entry.207: Went on sick parade and was sent straight to
Entry.209:
Was put on the Hospital train and sent to No. 14 General at the Casino Wamerou near Boulogne.

Went per ambulance to Boulougne where we went on board the Hospital Ship H.David reaching Dover at about 2 pm. Were put on a train and taken to Axminster where we again got on ambulances and came to a V.A.Hospital at Rhode Hill, Uplyme.
Entry.210: I was today allowed to get up for a while.
Entry.211: Walked over to Chalmers to see Mrs Hynes (Aust)
Entry.212: Went with Mrs Hine to see Mrs. Duncan another Aust.
Entry.213: Went up to London to Horsferry Rd and got my pass for 14 days leave. Went to see “A Better Ole"
Entry.214: Poked about all day and met Uncle George at night.
Entry.215: Went out to Hampton Court and went to see a “Little Bit of Fluff" at night.
Entry.216: Went out to see Mrs Shellshear in the evening
Entry.217: Came down to Eastbourne. It seems a very nice place I should like to see it in the summer.
Entry.218: Came back from Eastbourne by a late train.
Entry.219: Reported to H.2. and came down to No 1 Comoan Depot Sutton Vemy.
Entry.220: Went for classification and was marked B1 A3
Entry.222: Moved over to O.T.B. Sandhill Camp
Entry.223: Came to London on three days leave.
Entry.225: Marched in to Warminster and entrained at Folkestone.
Entry.226: Had two hours leave in Folkestone. Embarked at 2 pm. Reached Boulougne at about 5.30.
Entry.227: Slept on One Blanket Hill and entrained at 7 am.
Entry.228: Reached Rouen at 1 am. And disentrained at Harfleur at 4 am. Marched two miles to the base. Went through gas in the afternoon.
Entry.230: Church Parade this morning moved off at 2 pm and marched 6 miles to Havre , entrained and move out at 8 pm.
Entry.231: Reached the D.R.W. at Pernois at 12.30 pm.
Entry.232: Mounted guard at 3 pm and were relieved at 11 pm and warned for draft for the following morning.
Entry.233: Left at 8 am and marched 3 kilos past Flesselles to tents reaching here about 1 pm.
Entry.234: Moved off at 8 am and joined the battn at Querrieu at 12.30 pm.
Entry.235:
Feeling very much off colour today . 

We moved forward about six kilos to rear reserves near Bonney.
Entry.236: Fifty of us moved back to billets in La Honssoye
Entry.237: I went across to Querreu to see Eric.
Entry.238: Eric came over here for tea
Entry.240: Moved up and rejoined own platoon.
Entry.241: Moved up to supports and did a ration fatigue to front line.
Entry.242: Got back at 6.0 – and did ration fatigue again at night.
Entry.243: Got back at 4 am and moved off at 10 pm to take a strong post.
Entry.244: Got out all night and crawled up to the post and rushed it but found the birds had flown, someone saw them clear out before we got there handed over the post to A coy came back. Did ration fatigue again at night.
Entry.250: Reported out to B.H. 2 and was sent out to horse lines to report to a Raiding School
Entry.251: Reached horse lines at 2 am and went across to Landonette for my pack
Entry.252: Caught a lorry to Ailly-sur-Somme where we got a train to Abbeville.
Entry.253: Stayed at Rest Camp all night and got a train to Boulougne at 7 am arriving at 2 pm. Went by Mortor bus from there to Hardelot Plage to the school
Entry.254: Some of the sisters from the hospital
Entry.255:
General) gave all the Aussies and N.Z.s from the school a picnic in the evening.

We had a great time.
Entry.257: Went into Bologne by lorry and went by train to Pernois.
Entry.258: Went by lorry to Allonville Wood found the batt was at St Vast and had to go back.
Entry.260: Gave demonstrations in conjunct with tanks and moved up in lorries to Duors
Entry.261: Drew extra waterbottles, iron rations, ammunition, and bombs.
Entry.262:
Moved off at 4.30 am and followed on behind the advance as reserve brigade. Through 

Warfusse –Aban Court as far as Bayonvillons - here we dug possies for ourselves
Entry.264: Moved back to Fouilloy near Corbie in the afternoon
Entry.265: Had a spell all day. Beside a canal here where we can swim
Entry.267: Moved off about 11 am and marched to a wood the other side of Caix about twelve miles.
Entry.269: Did nothing all day and moved across to Reginald Wood near Morcourt at night.
Entry.270: Moved up about four kilos as reserves at night. Near Mericourt- sur- Somme
Entry.271: Went out for billeting party at night and were told to proceed to Hamelot about twelve kilos.
Entry.272: Order cancelled and had to return to Lena Wood and afterwards got possies in Hazlewood for the batt which arrived about midnight.
Entry.273: Did nothing but walk three kilos for a swim
Entry.274: Orders to move up at 1 AM to some place as reserves to another div doing a stunt.
Entry.276: Remained here all the time doing nothing
Entry.277: Moved off at 11 am and moved up to just behind Belloy
Entry.278: Moved off at 6.30 am and moved up to Barleux about three miles.
Entry.279: Moved off at 11 am and marched across about five kilos crossing the canal and river and stopping in a ravine at night.
Entry.280: Moved off at 4.30 am up through Halle to front line and “hopped the bags" at 6.15 am. We went about two kilos into Peronne taking numbers of prisoners Held the bigger part of the village at night.
Entry.281: The remainder of the village was taken today by B coy and the 58th. We were relieved at night coming out to the trenches we hopped off from.
Entry.282: Moved off at 6 am. Recrossed the canal and were back about three kilos.
Entry.283: I went back into Peronne to mark some of the captured guns.
Entry.284: Had a swim in the canal and moved off at night to deep dugouts near
Entry.285: Moved at 7 am and crossed the canal and followed up as reserves to troops following up Fritz as he evacuated to just in front of Le Mesnil for a few days spell.
Entry.286: Moved off at 6 am and moved up about 5 kilos to the left of Estrees
Entry.287: Moved back to Le Mesnil for a few days spell.
Entry.288: Church parade in the morning in afternoon parade to tell us the battalion is to broken up.
Entry.289: Battalion parade to be spoken to by the Brigadier.
Entry.290:
Paraded and were detailed to our new battalions.

I was detailed to 56th Batt. The N.C.O.s were called out and marched off the men are still over there.
Entry.291: Brigade sports. Received orders to report back to the Battn.
Entry.292: Full marching order parade in the morning and moved off at 6 oclock and marched about ten miles where we bivouacked in a wood.
Entry.293: Rained all day but we did not move.
Entry.294: Moved off at 8 am. And followed up the attack by the Yanks, stopped in a trench just behind Bellicourt.
Entry.295: Moved off at 3 am to trenches beyond Stenroy where we hopped over and went almost into Entrees. Moved over to the left in the afternoon and took over the front line from the 58th, and had a listening post out in front.
Entry.297: Division went through us at 6 am and moved forward, we came back to Bellicourt for breakfast and then moved back about three miles to Villeret.
Entry.298: Moved off at 10 am and marched back to Le Mesnil about 13 miles where we got our packs and blankets.
Entry.299: Moved off at 8 am and entrained at Peronne and came back to near Abbeville and marched out to Hamicourt about seven miles; arriving about 11pm.
Entry.300:
Moved off at 7 am and marched (full marching order) sixteen kilos to Abbeville and entrained. 18 hours in the train and detrained at Bertry and marched eleven

Kilos to Bungny
Entry.301: Marched fifteen kilos to Rejet-de-Beaulieu. This place is rather badly knocked about and all people are absolutely cowed
Entry.302: Rested today. Received a cable from home.
Entry.303: Marched seven kilos to La Groise
Entry.305: Church parade in the morning and just at tea time I was sent for to report to H.2 when they told me that the King had been pleased to award me the V.C.
Entry.307: Got my blighty pass, Have to catch the train tomorrow morning the other side of Le Cateau. Worked my way by various means to Vaux Andigny
Entry.308: Entrained at 4.30 am – reached Boulogne at 9 pm spent the night in the rest camp
Entry.309: Embarked at 9 am and reached Victoria station at 4.30 pm. Reported to H.2 and got fixed up . Spent the evening with the Shellshears.
Entry.310: Went to the Decorations office and found that my name has not yet come through the Gazette. There will be trouble over it coming through Battn orders before it appears. Expect it through on the
Entry.312: Came down to Eastbourne and spent the evening at the Broomes.
Entry.313: Great excitement when they saw the news in the paper. .Returned to London.
Entry.314:
Took Doris to a matinee and caught the midnight train for Torquay. Spent the two day at Aunt Juneys

Came back as far as Lyme Regis.
Entry.315: Spent the day writing old friends.
Entry.316: Returned to London and went to stay over Xmas with the Shellshears.
Entry.317: The girls made me go to a dance which I enjoyed immensely
Entry.318: Vic and I caught the 10.15 pm train for Edinburgh
Entry.319: Arrived at about 8.0 am it is wet and the place looks deserted.
Entry.320: Went out to the Docks at Leith to see a German sub and went to see Mrs. Peck
Entry.321: Saw St Giles Cathedral and went to the Jenner Social in the evening where we saw the old year out.
Entry.322:
Jan.1919

And the New year in, Got home at 1.15 am.

The place is quiet today. No trains or busses running and all shops closed. Went to a whist drive in the evening.
Entry.323: Caught the 10 am train back to London and arrived about 9 pm. The King is out of town so am returning to France.
Entry.324: Went to P.O. for mail and spent the evening with the Shellshears.
Entry.325: Caught the train from Victoria at 6am and crossed from Dover to Boulogne on a hospital ship and went to One Blanket Hill for the night.
Entry.326: Reveille at 5 am and entrained about seven and started at twelve and spent the rest of the day in the train
Entry.327:
Got off the train at 6 am at Rusmes and got another back to Soman.

, Walked eight kilos to Bpehain and got a train to Cambrai, saw the R.T.O. and got a train back to Soman
Entry.328: Caught a train at 5 am and arrrived at Charleroi at 1 pm and went to Corps Rest Camp.
Entry.329: Got a lorry to Beaumont Abbey 26 kilos and another from there nearly to Livry where I joined the Batt.
Entry.330: Moved about eight kilos and a place called Johs St Gary.
Entry.331: On guard today and the platoon moved to fresh billets
Entry.334: Moved back to billets in Savery
Entry.335: Moved about two kilos to new billets.
Entry.336: Had to move back again today as the billets were required for another brigade passing through.
Entry.338: Caught the 5.30 pm train from Charleroi to Brusselles.
Entry.339:
Caught the 8.40 am to Bruges and spent the rest of the day looking at the town.

In the central square are the Guild Hall and State Prison. The belfry with 48 bells build in 1619, the house where Charles 11 spent most of his exile. Behind the Guild Hall are the fish markets. 

From there we went out to the docks where we saw a U boat hit by a British bomb. 

At the cemetery we saw Captain Fryall Grave and afterwards inspected the cathedral.
Entry.340: Caught the 7.00 am train to Ostend and caught the tram out to Zee Brugge where we saw the Mole. The S.S.Brussels (Capt.Fryall boat ) has been sunk in the mouth of the harbour by Fritz before he left. Then we went round to the mouth of the canal and saw the Iris and Dafodil. Then we returned to Ostend and saw the Vindictive after which we lunched and caught the train back to Brusselles.
Entry.341: Caught the 2 pm. Train to Charleroi and returned to bivy that night.
Entry.342: Got a blighty pass and caught the boat train from Charleroi at 9 pm.
Entry.344: Arrived Folkestone at 10.15 am and caught first train to London arriving at 1 pm.
Entry.346: Went down to Eastbourne and spent two days.
Entry.347:
Invested today at the Palace.

`18th

Went to Torquay for Easter and returned on the
Entry.349: Saw the march from in front of Australia House
Entry.350: Came down to Sutton Veny to No 2 Command Depot.
Entry.351: Was transferred from Early Repatriation Camp to No 14 Quarter`
Entry.352: Moved off at 8 am. To Warminster where we entrained to Devonport where we embarked on H.M.A.T. Devanha at 3 pm.
Entry.353: Sailed at 2 pm. Having a good run so far.
Entry.354: Passed Gibraltar early in the morning
Entry.355: Reached Port Said at about 5 am. and remained all day . Had a swimming carnival in the afternoon.
Entry.356: Left at 3 am. and got down the canal as far as The Great Bitter Lakes where we had to wait as we had no searchlight on board.
Entry.357: Reached Suez at about 8 am. after starting at 4 am. stayed a couple of hours and then moved on.
Entry.358: Saw the Southern Cross tonight for the first time on the trip.
Entry.359: Had an Empire Day concert by the Devonport Dinkums.
Entry.360: Reached Aden at 12.30 where we coaled . We were allowed off for a couple of hours. I was on the picquet. We pulled out at about 8.15
Entry.361: Reached Colombo at about 6.30 pm and nearly ran into a boat coming out of the port. It was a bit rough and we could not get the pilot on board so stood off till morning.
Entry.362: Came in at daylight and we taken ashore at about three and remained off till 6 pm. Had a very decent time in Colombo.
Entry.363: Kings birthday. We fuelled a bit at 3 pm. Before we left a squall came up and most of the boats on the harbour broke their moorings but the anchor still held.
Entry.364: We crossed the line some time this morning
Entry.365: Sports today.Wonderful sunset tonight, the finest I have seen.
Entry.367: Reached Fremantle at about 7.30 am and the ship was quarantined.
Entry.368: The men for W.A. went off on a barge to the quarantine station, this morning at 8 oclock and we pulled out immediately after,
Entry.369: Arrived off Adelaide at 10 pm. And anchored until morning.
Entry.370:
The ship was passed as clear and we pulled into the warf at 10am when the S.As

Disembarked. They were met on the warf by their people who travelled up to 

Adelaide with them on the train. 

We got off at 1 pm and were given a special train to the city which we left at 10.30 and returned to the boat.
Entry.372:
Arrived in port Phillip at 6 am. where we remained for three hours until the medical inspection was finished when 

We went on up the harbour . Arrived at Port Melbourne at one oclock and the Vics were disembarked almost immediately. Then we were allowed ashore. I was met on the warf by Mr Hiscox and his daughter and had afternoon tea with them. We had leave until midnight.
Entry.373: Pulled out at 7am and got clear of the port about 11.30
